<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">26</font></p>


<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">

<hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left">

</font></div>

<font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='26',FILE='C:\jms\mvangb\04-2752-1\task82816\2752-1-ba.htm',USER='mvangb',CD='Feb 27 14:48 2004' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
</font>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">RESULTS
OF OPERATIONS</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">Overview</font></i></b></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">During the beginning of
2003, our operating results reflected an overall increase in advertising
revenues experienced by the broadcasting industry, partially offset by the negative
effect of the war in Iraq.&#160; Excluding
the effect of political advertising revenue, we continued to see an increase in
local advertising spending primarily due to our direct mail initiatives and
growth in our largest categories of automotive and services.&#160; National sales declined due to lower
advertising spending primarily by soft drink, fast food and movie
advertisers.&#160;&#160;&#160; Due to the biennial
cycle for political races and elections, we expect to benefit in 2004 from
additional political revenues due to the Presidential and other federal, state
and local elections, as well as benefit from additional revenues from our
direct mail initiatives.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Our results also include
increased expenses reflecting continued expansion of our News Central
operations, our direct mail sales effort and our continued expenditures related
to our conversion to digital television.&#160;
Using our News Central model we continued to implement local news
programming, which brought our total news franchise to 38 stations in 31
markets with 13 of those stations in 11 markets operating under News
Central.&#160; Our focus for 2004 will
primarily be on adding additional news dayparts and converting certain existing
news stations to the more cost effective News Central model.&#160; We continue to target direct mail
advertisers and introduce the direct mail advertisers to television as a medium
to reach their customers.&#160; We are
expanding our direct mail initiatives with plans to add more mailings during
2004.&#160; We expect capital expenditures
for the year of approximately $40 million, as described later in this
section&nbsp;under the heading, <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Liquidity and Capital Resources</font></i>.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">Years Ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 and 2002</font></i></b></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Net income available to
common shareholders for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 was $14.0 million
or $0.16 per share, compared to a net loss of $574.8 million or a loss of $6.74
per common share for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002.&#160; The primary reason for the reduction in the
net loss was the adoption of SFAS No. 142, <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets</font></i>
during the first quarter of 2002.&#160; As a
result of adopting SFAS No. 142, we recorded an impairment charge of $566.4
million, related to our broadcast licenses and goodwill, which was reflected as
a cumulative effect of a change in accounting principle in our consolidated
statement of operations, net of related tax benefit of $30.4 million during the
first quarter of 2002.&#160; We also recorded
an unrealized gain on derivative instruments of $17.4 million for the year
ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 compared to an unrealized loss on derivative
instruments of $30.9 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002.&#160;&#160; These were non-cash charges which had no
effect on our liquidity or capital resources currently or prospectively.&#160; (See <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Note 1, Summary of Significant Accounting Policies,
Note 3, Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets and Note 7, Derivative Instruments</font></i>
in the Notes to our Consolidated Financial Statements<i><font style="font-style:italic;">.</font></i>)</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Net broadcast revenues
decreased to $661.8 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 from
$670.5 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, or 1.3%.&#160; During the year ended December&nbsp;31,
2003, we had decreased revenue due to cyclical or non-recurring events as
follows:&#160; $2.2 million related to the
war in Iraq, $23.1 million related to political advertising, $1.6 million
related to the Super Bowl and $1.0 million related to the Olympics.&#160; The decline in Super Bowl revenue occurred
because the Super Bowl aired on our eight ABC stations during 2003 versus our
twenty FOX stations during 2002.&#160; The
Super Bowl aired on our three CBS stations in 2004 and will air on our twenty
Fox stations in 2005 and on our eight ABC stations in 2006.&#160; The decreased revenue due to cyclical or
non-recurring events was greatly offset by increased revenue of $14.7 million
related to our direct mail initiative.&#160;
From a revenue category standpoint, the year ended December&nbsp;31,
2003 was positively impacted by higher advertising revenue generated from the
automotive, professional service, school, paid programming, restaurant and home
product sectors, offset by decreases in political, soft drink, fast food,
movie, telecommunication and retail sectors.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">During the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2003, national revenues decreased to $251.9 million or 7.4%,
from $271.9 million during the same period last year.&#160; National political revenues decreased $16.5 million or
82.1%.&#160; During the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2003, local revenues increased to $379.2 million or 2.8% from
$369.0 million during the same period last year.&#160; Local political revenues decreased $6.5 million or 79.8%,
offsetting 1.8% of the increase in total local revenues.&#160; The decrease in political revenues was
primarily the result of many more elections held during the 2002 period, as
compared to the same period in 2003.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">National revenues, excluding
political revenues, decreased $3.4 million to $248.3 million or 1.4%, during
the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 from $251.7 million for the same period
last year.&#160; Local revenues, excluding
political revenues, increased $16.7 million to $377.5 million or 4.6%, during
the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 from $360.8 million for the same period
last year.&#160; Excluding political
revenues, national revenues declined due to lower advertising spending
primarily in the soft drink, fast food, telecommunications, and movie
sectors.&#160; The increase in local revenues
is related to our continued</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">27</font></p>


<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">

<hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left">

</font></div>

<font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='27',FILE='C:\jms\mvangb\04-2752-1\task82816\2752-1-ba.htm',USER='mvangb',CD='Feb 27 14:48 2004' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
</font>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">focus on local sales and
our direct mail conversion initiative that, as noted above, generated increased
revenues of $14.7 million during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2003, as
compared to the same period last year.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">From a network affiliate
perspective, broadcast revenue from time sales at our FOX affiliates, which
represents 37.6% of the total, decreased $3.8 million to $237.1 million, or
1.6% during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 from $240.9 million for the
same period last year.&#160; Excluding the
political revenue decrease of $4.7 million in the year ended December&nbsp;31,
2003 as compared to the same period last year, our FOX affiliate would have
experienced growth of 0.4%.&#160; Our ABC,
CBS, and NBC network affiliates, representing 16.6%, 7.4%, and 4.2%,
respectively of total net time sales experienced similar results.&#160; Excluding political revenue decreases in the
year ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 as compared to the same period last year of
$9.5 million, $4.5 million, and $2.9 million, respectively, ABC, CBS, and NBC
affiliates would have experienced growth of 2.6%, 2.5%, and 5.5%.&#160; Our UPN and WB affiliates experienced growth
for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 excluding political revenue, of 9.4%
and 2.2%, respectively, compared with the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">During the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2003, the G1440 operating divisions&#146; revenue that related to
software development and consulting increased by $0.4 million to $4.7 million,
or 9.3%, from $4.3 million for the same period last year.&#160; Other operating divisions&#146; revenue related
to our interest in Acrodyne increased by $9.9 million because beginning
January&nbsp;1, 2003, we commenced consolidating the financial statements of
Acrodyne and discontinued accounting for the investments under the equity
method of accounting.&#160; Other operating
divisions&#146; expenses increased by $10.3 million, of which $11.4 million resulted
from the consolidation of Acrodyne, offset by a decrease in general and
administrative costs of $1.1 million for G1440, primarily related to the
consolidation from three offices to one office and continued focus on cost
reduction, for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2003, as compared to the year
ended December&nbsp;31, 2002.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Station production
expenses were $147.9 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 compared
to $140.1 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, an increase of
$7.8 million, or 5.6%.&#160; The increase in station
production costs primarily related to an increase in promotion costs of $3.3
million during the February&nbsp;2003 ratings sweeps compared to
February&nbsp;2002, when we reduced our spending due to direct competition from
the Olympics, offset by decreased promotional spending in the second and third
quarter of $0.3 million in six of our markets.&#160;
We also experienced increases in spending of $2.6 million for the News
Central expansions in our Tampa, Flint, Milwaukee, Birmingham, Las Vegas,
Cincinnati, and Greensboro markets, Nielsen rating service fees of $1.1 million
related to new contracts for eleven stations, $1.1 million in affiliate fees,
engineering costs of $0.5 million related to news expansions in the fourth
quarter, the full year effect of the addition of our WNAB-TV outsourcing
agreement during the second quarter of 2002, and increased electricity costs
related to digital TV of $0.4 million.&#160;
These increases were offset by a decrease in programming and production
costs of $0.5 million related to our outsourcing and LMA agreements, a decrease
in music license fees of $0.3 million, and other miscellaneous decreases of
$0.1 million. Going forward we will continue our news expansion by bringing
news to new markets, converting certain existing news stations to the more cost
effective News Central model, and adding additional news dayparts at other
stations.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Station selling, general
and administrative expenses were $145.9 million for the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2003 compared to $143.3 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31,
2002, an increase of $2.6 million, or 1.8%. We experienced increases in direct
mail marketing campaign costs of $3.2 million, sales expense for the addition
of our WNAB-TV outsourcing agreement of $0.5 million, an increase in sales
compensation costs of $2.9 million, legal fees of $0.5 million, and
miscellaneous general and administrative costs of $0.1 million.&#160; We will continue our direct mail initiative
with plans to add additional mailings during 2004.&#160; These increases were offset by a decrease in selling, general and
administrative expenses related to a reduction of $2.4 million in bad debt
expense as a result of improvements in the economy, national commissions of
$0.9 million, expenses for Cunningham of $0.6 million, trade expense of $0.3
million, property taxes of $0.3 million, and vacation expense of $0.1 million.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">Depreciation and amortization decreased $</font>14.5 </font>million to $171.4 million
for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 from $185.9 million for the
year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002.&#160; The
decrease in depreciation and amortization for the year ended December&nbsp;31,
2003, as compared to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 was related to a
decrease in amortization of $20.2 million related to our program contract costs
and NRV adjustments as a result of a lower cost of additions of new programming
during 2003 as compared to 2002 and a decrease in NRV adjustments, offset by an
increase in fixed asset depreciation of $5.7 million related to our property
additions, primarily resulting from our digital television conversion and
centralized news investments.&#160;&#160; We
expect amortization related to our program contract costs will decrease from
2003 but it will be a smaller decrease than we had from 2002 to 2003.&#160; We will have additional property additions
in 2004 related to the completion of our digital roll-out and the expansion of
our news.</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Corporate general and
administrative expenses increased $5.5 million to $25.3 million for the year
ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 from $19.8 million for the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2002, or 27.8%. Corporate general and administrative expense</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">28</font></p>


<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">

<hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left">

</font></div>

<font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='28',FILE='C:\jms\mvangb\04-2752-1\task82816\2752-1-ba.htm',USER='mvangb',CD='Feb 27 14:48 2004' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
</font>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">represents the cost to
operate our corporate headquarters location.&#160;
Such costs include corporate departmental salaries, bonuses and fringe
benefits, directors and officers&#146; liability insurance, rent,
telecommunications, consulting fees, legal and accounting fees and director
fees.&#160; Corporate departments include
executive committee, treasury, finance and accounting, human resources,
technology, corporate relations, legal, sales, operations, purchasing,
programming, corporate direct mail administration and centralized news.&#160; The increase in corporate general and
administrative expenses primarily relates to an increase of $3.2 million for
the launch of our centralized news and weather format as well as the
centralization of our promotion and programming operations, consulting fees of
$0.9 million, increased costs for telecommunications related to upgrades of
$0.5 million, insurance costs of $0.5 million, administrative expenses related
to our direct mail initiative of $0.2 million and other miscellaneous increases
in expense of $0.2 million.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Interest expense
increased to $128.2 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 from
$126.5 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 or 1.3%.&#160; The increase in interest expense resulted
from the higher interest expense from the redemption of HYTOPS, offset by
financing of indebtedness at lower interest rates during July, November, and
December&nbsp;2002 and May 2003.&#160; Subsidiary
trust minority interest expense decreased to $11.2 million for the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2003 from $23.9 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31,
2002, or 53.1%, as a result of the redemption of HYTOPS in June&nbsp;of 2003.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Our income tax provision
was $15.7 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 compared to an
income tax provision of $4.2 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31,
2002.&#160; Our tax rate changed to a
provision in 2003, from a benefit in 2002, because we reported taxable net
income in 2003, compared to a net loss in 2002.&#160; The effective tax rate from continuing operations decreased
slightly to 40.8% for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 from 41.0% for the
year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">Years Ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 and 2001</font></i></b></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">During 2002, we continued
to see strengthening in our broadcast business even without regard to the
significant inflow of political advertising revenues. Net broadcast revenues,
excluding political revenues, grew despite the economy not being in a full
recovery and a threat of war looming. The growth came from both the local and
national markets. Throughout 2002, our quarterly revenues, excluding political,
grew at successively higher growth rates.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Net loss available to
shareholders for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 was $574.8 million or
net loss of $6.74 per share compared to net loss of $138.1&nbsp;million or loss
of $1.64 per share for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001. The net loss for
the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 was largely the result of the cumulative
effect of change in accounting principle of $566.4&nbsp;million net of taxes.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">As a result of adopting
SFAS No.&nbsp;142, we recorded an impairment charge of $566.4&nbsp;million
related to our broadcast licenses and goodwill reflected as a cumulative effect
of a change in accounting principle on our consolidated statement of
operations, net of the related tax benefit of $30.4&nbsp;million during the
first quarter 2002. This was a non-cash charge which had no effect on our
liquidity or capital resources currently or prospectively. Without this charge,
our net loss available to shareholders during the year ended December&nbsp;31,
2002 would have been $8.4&nbsp;million. (See <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Note 3, Goodwill and Other Intangible
Assets</font></i>, in our Notes to our Consolidated Financial Statements.)</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Net broadcast revenues
increased to $670.5 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 from
$623.8&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 or 7.5%. The year
ending December&nbsp;31, 2002 was positively impacted by higher advertising
revenues generated from the political, automotive, services, restaurants, home
products, schools and beer/wine, offset by weakness in the fast food and soft
drink sectors. During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, national revenues
increased to $271.9&nbsp;million or 7.0%, from $254.0&nbsp;million during 2001.
National political revenues increased $19.1&nbsp;million or 1,888.0%. During
the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, local revenues increased to
$369.0&nbsp;million, or 8.3%, from $340.6&nbsp;million during 2001. Local
political revenues increased $6.9&nbsp;million, or 556.0%, representing 2.0% of
the increase in total local revenues. The increase in political revenues was
primarily the result of the several primary and general elections during 2002.
During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, we had increased revenue of $6.6&nbsp;million
related to our direct mail initiative, $2.2&nbsp;million related to the Super
Bowl and $1.0&nbsp;million related to the Olympics. During the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2001 we estimate that we had decreased revenues of
$5.4&nbsp;million related to the terrorist attacks of September&nbsp;11, 2001.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">National revenues,
excluding political revenues, declined $1.3&nbsp;million to $251.7&nbsp;million
or 0.5%, during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 from $253.0&nbsp;million
during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001. Local revenues, excluding political
revenues, increased $21.5&nbsp;million to $360.8&nbsp;million, or 6.3%, during
the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 from $339.3&nbsp;million during 2001.</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">29</font></p>


<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">

<hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left">

</font></div>

<font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='29',FILE='C:\jms\mvangb\04-2752-1\task82816\2752-1-ba.htm',USER='mvangb',CD='Feb 27 14:48 2004' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
</font>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Same station basis is a
comparison of only the stations that we owned or provided programming and
operating services pursuant to an LMA for both entire years ending
December&nbsp;31, 2002 and 2001. Comparing results on a &#147;same stations basis&#148;
enhances the understanding of our business and revenue growth because we are able
to disclose our ability to grow revenue at television stations owned and
operated during the two most recent fiscal years. This enables us to eliminate
the impact of partial year activity of acquisitions and dispositions occurring
during the two most recent fiscal years. While reporting actual historical
results for all stations owned and operated during the fiscal year is vital to
understanding our performance, we believe that it is important to analyze
stations owned during both fiscal years as a measure of our operating
performance. On a same station basis for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002,
national revenues including political revenues increased $17.2&nbsp;million, or
6.8%, and local sales increased $29.4&nbsp;million, or 8.8%, over 2001. The
increase in national revenues was primarily due to the increase in political
revenues. The increase in local revenues is related to our continued focus on
developing a strong local sales force at each of our stations.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In addition, for the year
ended December&nbsp;31, 2001, the events of September&nbsp;11, 2001 had a
direct impact on the revenues of media related businesses. The terrorist
attacks led to the pre-emption and cancellation of advertisements, which caused
an estimated $5.4&nbsp;million revenue loss during 2001.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The network affiliations
that experienced the largest revenue growth for the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2002 were our NBC and CBS affiliates which increased 21.3%
and 19.3%, respectively, compared with the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001.
Our ABC and FOX affiliates experienced revenue growth of 11.3% and 9.1%,
respectively, for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 as compared to the year
ended December&nbsp;31, 2001. The WB affiliates&#146; revenue increased 2.0% for the
year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 as compared to the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2001. The UPN affiliates&#146; revenue decreased 1.7% for the year
ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 as compared to the year ended December&nbsp;31,
2001.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Other revenue decreased
to $4.3&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 from
$6.9&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 or 37.7%. The
decrease in revenue relates to a decreased demand for services from our
software development and consulting company, due to the slow economy and a
decrease in revenue of $0.4&nbsp;million related to the closing of the San Francisco
office during the first quarter 2001.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Station production
expenses decreased $2.6&nbsp;million to $140.1&nbsp;million for the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2002 from $142.7&nbsp;million for the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2001. The decrease in operating costs related to a decrease
of $6.5&nbsp;million related to our LMA fees, due to the acquisition of 15
television broadcast licenses during the three months ended March&nbsp;31,
2002. Our results of operations from LMA stations are typically lower than they
would have been if we had owned the televisions stations. The results of
operations of our LMA stations was lower because of higher programming and
production expenses due to the incurrence of the LMA fees.&#160; News costs decreased by $3.5&nbsp;million
related to the discontinuation of news at our stations KDNL-TV, St. Louis,
Missouri and WXLV-TV, Winston-Salem, North Carolina. In addition, other
miscellaneous production expense decreased by $0.4&nbsp;million. These
decreases were offset by increases of $2.1&nbsp;million in engineering costs,
$1.7&nbsp;million related to music license fees, $1.5&nbsp;million in
programming fees related to increased costs for affiliate agreements,
$1.3&nbsp;million in rating service fees, and $1.2&nbsp;million related to
increased promotional spending during the May Sweeps.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Station selling, general
and administrative expenses increased $0.4&nbsp;million to $149.4&nbsp;million
for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 from $149.0&nbsp;million for the year
ended December&nbsp;31, 2001. Sales commissions increased by $3.3&nbsp;million
as a result of improved sales. This increase was offset by decreases of
$1.6&nbsp;million related to a decrease in national representation commissions,
$1.2&nbsp;million related to a reduction in bad debt expense, and
$0.1&nbsp;million related to traffic costs.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Depreciation and
amortization decreased $74.6&nbsp;million to $185.9&nbsp;million for the year
ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 from $260.5&nbsp;million for the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2001. The decrease in depreciation and amortization for the
year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 as compared to the year ended December&nbsp;31,
2001 was related to the adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;142 which resulted in the
discontinuation of amortization of our goodwill and broadcast licenses.
Amortization of intangible assets decreased by $93.0&nbsp;million, offset by an
increase aggregating $15.0&nbsp;million related to amortization of our program
contract costs and net realizable value adjustments related to our addition of
new programming primarily consisting of Dharma&nbsp;&amp; Greg and
Will&nbsp;&amp; Grace as well as write downs primarily related to additional
seasons for Frasier, Drew Carey, Spin City, Just Shoot Me, and Third Rock from
the Sun and an increase in fixed asset depreciation of $3.4&nbsp;million
related to our property additions, primarily resulting from our digital
television conversion.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">For the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2002, we did not incur any restructuring charges, impairment
and write-down of long-lived assets (except for the impact of adopting SFAS
No.&nbsp;142) or contract termination costs. During the three months ended
March&nbsp;31, 2001, we offered a voluntary early retirement program to our
eligible employees and implemented a restructuring program to</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">30</font></p>


<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">

<hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left">

</font></div>

<font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='30',FILE='C:\jms\mvangb\04-2752-1\task82816\2752-1-ba.htm',USER='mvangb',CD='Feb 27 14:48 2004' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
</font>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">reduce operating and
overhead costs. As a result, we reduced our staff by 186 employees and incurred
a restructuring charge of $2.3&nbsp;million, which is included in the
accompanying consolidated statements of operations. During September&nbsp;2001,
our station KDNL-TV in St. Louis, Missouri, discontinued programming its local
news broadcast. As a result, we incurred a restructuring charge of $1.1&nbsp;million.
During December&nbsp;2001, WXLV-TV in Winston-Salem, North Carolina
discontinued programming its local news broadcast. As a result we incurred a
restructuring charge of $0.3&nbsp;million. The restructuring charges related to
severance and operating contract termination costs. During the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2001, we incurred an impairment and write-down of long-lived
assets of $5.5&nbsp;million and contract termination costs of
$5.1&nbsp;million.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Operating income
increased $146.6&nbsp;million to $184.6&nbsp;million for the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2002 from $38.0&nbsp;million for the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2001, or 385.8%. The net increase in operating income for the
year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 as compared to the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2001 was primarily attributable to a decrease in amortization
due to the adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;142 which resulted in the discontinuation
of amortization of our goodwill and FCC licenses offset by an increase in
program contract amortization expense and property and equipment depreciation
expense as discussed above. Operating income was also affected by a decrease in
program and production expenses due to the acquisition of 15 television
broadcast licenses resulting in our ability to operate at a cost lower than
operating those stations as LMA structures and reduced spending for sweeps
promotion due to direct competition from the Olympics. During the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2001, we incurred a loss of $16.1&nbsp;million related to a
write down charge of long-lived assets. This charge is comprised of goodwill
related to our software development company and our station KBSI-TV in Paducah,
Kentucky, and a write off of fixed assets which represent the net book value of
damaged, obsolete or abandoned property. We also incurred contract termination
costs of $5.1&nbsp;million and restructuring charges of $3.7&nbsp;million as a
result of a voluntary early retirement program and cancellation of local news
programs during the year ended December&nbsp;2001. We did not incur any
write-down charge of long-lived assets, contract termination or restructuring
charges for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Interest expense
decreased to $126.5&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 from
$143.6&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001, or 11.9%. The
decrease in interest expense for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 resulted
from the refinancing of indebtedness at lower interest rates during
December&nbsp;2001, March&nbsp;2002, July&nbsp;2002, November&nbsp;2002 and
December&nbsp;2002 and an overall lower interest rate environment.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Our income tax provision
was $4.2 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 compared to an
income tax benefit of $59.6 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001.
The effective tax rate from continuing operations increased to 41.0% for the
year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, from 31.3% for the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2001.&#160; The increase is
primarily because (prior to the implementation of SFAS No. 142 for 2002) our
reported income in 2001 was reduced by amortization of goodwill, which was
non-deductible for tax purposes.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Loss related to
investments decreased to $1.2&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31,
2002 as compared to $7.6&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31,
2001. The loss related to investments for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002
primarily relates to a loss of $1.4&nbsp;million as a result of a write down of
our investment in Allegiance Capital, a loss of $0.1&nbsp;million from the sale
of our interest in Synergy Brands,&nbsp;Inc., offset by a gain of
$0.3&nbsp;million related to proceeds of a settlement to shareholders of Acrodyne.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">We recognized income from
discontinued operations of $7.9&nbsp;million, which includes a gain on the sale
of WTTV-TV in Indianapolis, Indiana of $7.5&nbsp;million for the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2002 as compared to a loss from discontinued operations of $52,000
for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">For the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2002, we reported a $9.8&nbsp;million loss related to the
call premium and write-off of deferred financing costs and interest, net of
taxes, resulting from the repayment of our $300.0&nbsp;million Term Loan
Facility and 1998 Bank Credit Agreement and the early redemption of our 9%
senior subordinated notes due 2007 and our 8.75% senior subordinated notes due
2007.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">For the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2001, we reported a $14.2&nbsp;million loss related to the
call premium and write-off of deferred financing costs and interest, net of
taxes, resulting from the early redemption of our 10% senior subordinated notes
due 2005, and amendments to our bank credit agreement.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">As a result of the
implementation of SFAS No. 133,<i><font style="font-style:italic;"> Accounting for Derivative Instruments and Hedging </font></i>Activities,
one of our derivatives does not qualify for special hedge accounting treatment.
Therefore, this derivative must be recognized in the balance sheet at fair
market value and the changes in fair market value are reflected in earnings. As
a result, we recognized $32.2 million of losses during 2001 and $30.9 million
of losses during 2002.</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">31</font></p>


<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">

<hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left">

</font></div>

<font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='31',FILE='C:\jms\mvangb\04-2752-1\task82816\2752-1-ba.htm',USER='mvangb',CD='Feb 27 14:48 2004' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
</font>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">Recent Accounting Pronouncements</font></i></b></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">We adopted Statement of
Financial Accounting Standard (SFAS) No. 145, <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Rescission of FASB Statements Nos. 4,
44 and 64, Amendment of FASB Statement No,. 13 and Technical Corrections</font></i>
on January&nbsp;1, 2003.&#160; SFAS No. 145
requires us to record gains and losses on extinguishment of debt as a component
of income from continuing operations rather than as an extraordinary item and
we have reclassified such items for all periods presented.&#160; There are other provisions contained in SFAS
No. 145 that do not have a material effect on our financial statements.&#160; For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002,
net loss from continuing operations increased to $6.0 million from net income
of $3.9 million and the related loss per share increased to $0.19 per share
from $0.08 loss per share after we reclassified our extraordinary item.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In January&nbsp;2003, the
Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) issued Interpretation No. 46, <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Consolidation
of Variable Interest Entities, an Interpretation of Accounting Research
Bulletin (ARB) No. 51</font></i> (FIN 46).&#160;
FIN 46 introduces the variable interest consolidation model, which
determines control and consolidation based on potential variability in gains
and losses of the entity being evaluated for consolidation.&#160; The FASB delayed the effective date of FIN
46 for certain variable interest entities until the first interim period ending
after December&nbsp;15, 2003&#160; We are
currently assessing various transactions to determine whether they could be
considered a variable interest entity (VIE) and whether we would be the primary
beneficiary under the amended guidance of FIN 46.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">We have determined that
the unrelated third-party owner of WNAB-TV in Nashville may be a VIE and that
we may be the primary beneficiary of the variable interests as a result of the
terms of our outsourcing agreement, put options and call options. As a result,
we may be required to consolidate the assets and liabilities of WNAB-TV at
their fair market values as of March&nbsp;31, 2004 and we are currently
assessing the impact of consolidating WNAB-TV on our results of operations. &#160;We have not completed our analysis at this
time<i><font style="font-style:italic;">.&#160; </font></i>We made payments to the unrelated
third party owner of WNAB-TV of $2.3 million and $2.8 million related to our
outsourcing agreement for the twelve months ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 and
December&nbsp;31, 2002, respectively.&#160;
On January&nbsp;2, 2003, we made an $18.0 million non-refundable deposit
against the purchase price of the put or call option on the non-license
assets.&#160; We believe that our maximum
exposure to loss as a result of our involvement with WNAB-TV consists of the
fees that we pay related to the outsourcing agreement as well as any payments
that we would be required to make under the put options held by the current
owner related to the license and non-license assets.&#160; (See <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Note 9</font></i>, <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Commitments and Contingencies, WNAB
Options</font></i> in the Notes to our Consolidated Financial Statements.).</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">We have determined that
Cunningham Broadcasting Corporation (Cunningham) is a VIE and that we are the
primary beneficiary of the variable interests.&#160;
We already consolidate Cunningham; therefore, the implementation of FIN
46 will not have a material effect on our financial statements with respect to
our variable interest in Cunningham. We made LMA payments to Cunningham of $4.7
million, $4.0 million, and $11.8 million for the years ended December&nbsp;31,
2003, 2002 and 2001, respectively.&#160; We
received payments from Cunningham of $0.5 million and $0.2 million for the
years ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 and 2002, respectively. We believe that our
maximum exposure to loss as a result of our involvement with Cunningham
consists of the fees that we pay related to the LMA agreements as well as
payments that we would make as a result of exercising our option to acquire
Cunningham, which provides for an option exercise price based on a formula that
provides a 10% annual return to Cunningham. (See <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Note 9, Commitments and Contingencies</font></i>
in the Notes to our Consolidated Financial Statements.)</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">We are currently
evaluating the applicability of FIN 46 on our LMAs and outsourcing agreements
and the possible impact on our results of operations and financial
position.&#160; We are currently reviewing
these agreements to determine if the licensor represents a variable interest
entity to us.&#160; We believe the exposure
to loss because of our involvement with the license holder for each station is
minimal and can be measured by the incremental depreciation expense from the
addition of the fixed assets of the license holder.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In January&nbsp;2003, the
Emerging Issues Task Force (EITF) issued EITF 00-21, <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Accounting for Revenue Arrangements
with Multiple Deliverables</font></i>.&#160;
EITF 00-21 addresses the determination of whether an arrangement
involving multiple deliverables contains more than one unit of accounting and
how arrangement consideration should be measured and allocated to the separate
units of accounting in the arrangement.&#160;
EITF 00-21 does not otherwise change the applicable revenue recognition
criteria.&#160; We adopted issue 00-21 on
July&nbsp;1, 2003 and have determined that our direct mail agreements
constitute revenue arrangements with multiple deliverables that contain more
than one unit of accounting. Consequently, we allocate the consideration that
we receive for certain of these agreements between television accounting units
and direct mail accounting units and we recognize the revenue and related
expenses when the television spots are aired and when the direct mail pieces
are mailed, respectively.</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">32</font></p>


<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">

<hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left">

</font></div>

<font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">
